tit.e: Mikomai (Japanese ancient religious music and dancing dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual, played by shrine maidens each holding a small baton with bells)
Mikomai (Japanese ancient religious music and dancing dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual, played by shrine maidens each holding a small baton with bells)
tit.cmt: This seems a little long for a heading so I have reduced the length. Please check if this works.Also, I think the ordering of adjectives is incorrect here. It should be "ancient Japanese religious XXX" rather than "Japanese ancient religious XXX", shouldn't it?

sen.j: 巫女舞（みこまい・神子舞）とは、巫女によって舞われる神楽の舞の一つ。
sen.e: Mikomai (written in Japanese kanji character either as 巫女舞 or as 神子舞) is a type of dance by miko (shrine maidens) to perform Kagura (a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual.)

Mikomai (written in Japanese kanji character either as 巫女舞 or 神子舞) is a type of dance by miko (shrine maidens) to perform Kagura, a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual.
sen.cmt: "or as 神子舞"→"or 神子舞""Kagura (a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual.)"→"Kagura, a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in a Shinto ritual."
sen.e: Mikomai (written in Japanese kanji characters either as 巫女舞 or 神子舞) is a type of dance performed by miko (shrine maidens) in a Kagura performance (a sacred music and dancing performance dedicated to the Shinto gods).
sen.cmt: I think the plural is required for "kanji character". The other changes are mainly stylistic but would read more naturally to me.

sen.j: 巫女神楽（みこかぐら）・八乙女舞（やおとめまい）とも。
sen.e: Mikomai is also called "Mikokagura" (literally, "Kagura performed by miko maidens") and "Yaotomemai." (literally, "a dance by eight maidens.")
Mikomai is also called "Mikokagura" (literally, "Kagura performed by shrine maidens") and "Yaotomemai" (literally, "a dance by eight maidens").

sen.e: Mikomai is also called "Mikokagura" (literally, "Kagura performed by shrine maidens") and "Yaotomemai" (literally, "a dance by eight maidens").
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 古代日本において、祭祀を司る巫女自身の上に神が舞い降りるという神がかりの儀式のために行われた舞がもととなり、それが様式化して祈祷や奉納の舞となった。
sen.e: In ancient Japan, gods were believed to alight on shrine maidens who were engaged in serving for rituals for gods, when the maidens became possessed by gods through performing dances; which dances became later formalized and took the current form of dances for rogation and dedication to gods.

The dances performed by shrine maidens in ancient Japan, through which gods were believed to alight upon and possess the maidens who were performing the rituals for gods, where later formalized and took the current form of dances for solemn prayer and dedication to gods.
sen.cmt: Revised structure"rogation"→"solemn prayer"
sen.e: The dances performed by shrine maidens in ancient Japan, through which gods were believed to alight upon and possess the maidens who were performing the rituals for the gods, were later formalized and took the current form of dances for solemn prayer and dedication to the gods.
sen.cmt: This is a big improvement on the original translation (which was pretty hard to read).I do think that the definite article is required before "gods", however, as we are presumably talking about the Shinto gods rather than just any old gods. And "where" should have been "were".

sen.j: 前者（「神がかり系」）においては古来の神がかりや託宣の儀式の形式に則って回っては回り返すという動作を繰り返しながら舞うことなどでその身を清めてからその身に神を降すという、その古態を残すところもあるが、現在では優雅な神楽歌にあわせた舞の優美さを重んじた後者（「八乙女系」）がほとんどである。
sen.e: There still remains some traces of ancient style dancing, where miko maidens repeat whirling and whirling back following the traditional rules of rituals to clean their own bodies before being possessed to receive oracles from gods, but nowadays modern style of dances (represented by Yaotomemai) is dominant where elegance of dancing with graceful Kagurauta (chanting of Kagura) is emphasized.

Although some traces of ancient style dancing still remain, where shrine maidens repeat the motions of whirling and whirling back following traditional ritual rules to cleanse their bodies before being possessed to receive oracles from gods, modern-style dances that emphasize elegance of dancing with graceful chanting of Kagurauta song, represented by Yaotomemai, are dominant today.
sen.cmt: Revised sentence structure"There still remains..."→"Although...still remain""miko maidens"→"shrine maidens""clean"→"cleanse""nowadays"→"today""modern style of dances"→"modern-style dances""is""are""but today"→"today" etc.
sen.e: Although some traces of ancient style dancing still remain, where shrine maidens whirl back and forth in accordance with traditional ritual rules to cleanse their bodies before being possessed to receive oracles from the gods, modern-style dances (such as the Yaotomemai) that emphasize the elegance of the dancing with graceful chanting of Kagurauta songs are dominant today.
sen.cmt: The native checker has made a number of improvements but I think "repeat the motions of whirling and whirling back" sounds a bit odd. "whirl back and forth" would sound more natural to me. I also think that what is meant by "represented by Yaotomemai" is a bit unclear.

sen.j: 水干・緋袴・白足袋の装いに身を包んだ巫女が太鼓や笛、銅拍子などの囃子にあわせて鈴・扇・笹・榊・幣など依り代となる採物を手にした巫女が舞い踊る。
sen.e: The shrine maidens perform mikomai dances, being clad in suikan (everyday garment worn by commoners in ancient Japan), hibakama (scarlet Japanese pants for men) and shirotabi (white Japanese socks,) and holding various torimono (divine items to be held in hands) which are regarded as yorishiro (objects representative of a divine spirit) such as suzu (bells,) oogi (folding fans,) sasa (dwarf bamboos,) sakaki (branches of a kind of divine wood,) nusa (symbols of divinity made of cloth or paper and hung on a stick) and others, in harmony with hayashi (an orchestra of Japanese instruments) of drums, flutes, dobyoshi (two circular cymbals made of copper or iron) and so on.

The shrine maidens clad in suikan (everyday garments worn by commoners in ancient Japan), hibakama (scarlet Japanese pants for men) and shirotabi (white Japanese socks), and grasping various torimono (hand-held divine items) such as suzu (bells), oogi (folding fans), sasa (dwarf bamboos), sakaki (branches of a kind of divine wood) and nusa (symbols of divinity made of cloth or paper and hung on a stick) that are regarded as yorishiro (objects representative of a divine spirit), perform mikomai dances in harmony with a hayashi (an orchestra of Japanese instruments) that includes drums, flutes, dobyoshi (two circular cymbals made of copper or iron) and other instruments.

sen.e: In some areas of Kanto Region, mikomai dances are performed by masked dancers.
In some areas of the Kanto Region, mikomai dances are performed by masked dancers as well.

sen.j: 巫女舞の原点は神がかりの儀式にあったといわれている。
sen.e: Mikomai dances are said to have originated in Shinto rituals to make human spirits possessed by gods.
Mikomai dances are said to have originated in Shinto rituals in which humans were possessed by gods.
sen.cmt: " to make human spirits possessed"→"in which humans were possessed"
sen.e: Mikomai dances are said to have originated in Shinto rituals in which humans were possessed by gods.

sen.j: 採物を手にした巫女がまず身を清めるための舞を舞い、続いて順周り・逆周りに交互に回りながら舞う。
sen.e: Firstly, a shrine maiden holding torimono (divine items to be held in hands) dances a dance to clean her body, and then she continues whirling alternately in one direction and in reverse.
A shrine maiden grasping torimono (hand-held divine items) first dances a dance to cleanse her body, then continues whirling alternately in one direction and the reverse.
sen.cmt: Revised structure"holding"→"grasping""divine items to be held in hands"→"hand-held divine items""Firstly"→"first""clean"→"cleanse""and then she continues"→"then continues""and in reverse"→"and the reverse"
sen.e: A shrine maiden grasping torimono (hand-held divine items) first dances a dance to cleanse her body, then continues whirling alternately in one direction and the reverse.

sen.j: やがて、その旋回運動は激しくなり、次第に巫女は一種のトランス状態に突入してやがて神を自分の身に宿す（憑依）ことになる。
sen.e: Before long, her whirling action increases its intensity rapidly until she is thrown into a kind of trance to embrace ingression of gods ("hyoi" in other Japanese words, meaning "spirit possession" in English.)
Before long, her whirling motion increases in intensity until she is thrown into a trance to embrace the ingression of gods ("hyoi" in Japanese, meaning "spirit possession").

sen.j: 『古事記』・『日本書紀』において天岩屋戸の前で舞ったとされる天鈿女命の故事にその原型が見られ、その子孫とされた「猨女君」の女性達は代々神祇官の女官として神楽を奉納したとされている。
sen.e: The original pattern of Mikomai dance can be seen in "Kojiki" (literally, "Records of Ancient Matters") and "Nihonshoki" (literally, "Chronicles of Japan") as a historical event of Ame no Uzume no mikoto (a goddess of dawn and revelry) who performed a dance in front of Ama no Iwayato (a rock cave where Amaterasu, deity of the Sun, had hidden); and women of the Sarume no kimi (descendants of Ama no Uzume no mikoto) were reported to have been successively engaged in serving the Kagura dance to gods as court ladies of Jingikan (a department of worship in charge of clergy and Shinto rituals.)

The original pattern of mikomai dance can be seen in the "Kojiki" (A Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as a historical event of Ame no Uzume no mikoto (the goddess of dawn and revelry), who performed a dance in front of Ama no Iwayato (a rock cave where Amaterasu, deity of the Sun, had hidden), and women of the Sarume no kimi (descendants of Ama no Uzume no mikoto) were reported to have been successively engaged in offering the Kagura dance to gods as court ladies of Jingikan (a department of worship in charge of clergy and Shinto rituals.)

sen.e: The original pattern of mikomai dance can be seen in the "Kojiki" (A Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as a historical event of Ame no Uzume no mikoto (the goddess of dawn and revelry), who performed a dance in front of Ama no Iwayato (a rock cave where Amaterasu, deity of the Sun, had hidden), and women of the 'Sarume no kimi' (descendants of Ama no Uzume no mikoto) were reported to have been successively engaged in offering the Kagura dance to gods as court ladies of Jingikan (a department of worship in charge of clergy and Shinto rituals).
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせクォーテーション追加、ピリオドの位置移動

sen.j: 平安時代の宮廷で舞われたとされる「猨女」・「御巫」（『貞観儀式』）はいずれも巫女舞であったと推定されている。
sen.e: Those dances performed in Imperial court during Heian era are all presumed to be Mikomai, such as "Sarume" (literallly, "women regarded as descendants of Ama no Uzume, and engaged in offering Kagura dances to gods") and "mikannagi" (literally, "a woman in charge of dedicating various rituals to gods) both of which are referred to in the book titled "Jogan gishiki" (literally, "ceremonial manners observed during Jogan period".)

The dancers who performed at the Imperial Court during the Heian period are all presumed to have been mikomai, such as "Sarume" (women regarded as descendants of Ama no Uzume, and engaged in offering Kagura dances to gods) and "mikannagi" (a woman in charge of dedicating various rituals to gods), both of which are referred to in the book titled "Jogan gishiki" (the ceremonial manners observed during Jogan period).
sen.cmt: "Those dances performed in Imperial court during Heian era"→"The dancers who performed at the Imperial Court during the Heian period""to be Mikomai"→"to have been mikomai"Deleted "literallly" and "literally"Moved period outside of parentheses

sen.cmt: 'Sarume', 'Mikannagi', および "Jogan Gishiki"とし、Jogan period→Jogan eraに修正

sen.j: 『拾遺集』によれば、920年（延喜20年）に奈良の春日大社で「八乙女」と呼ばれる巫女達による神楽が舞われたと記録されている。
sen.e: According to a description in the "Shuishu" (literally, "collection of gleanings" or an imperial anthology of Japanese waka poetry,) a Kagura dance was performed by miko called "Yaotome" (literally, "eight maidens") at Kasugataisha Shrine in Nara in 920.

sen.cmt: 一部シングルクォーテーションに変更、Kasuga Taisha Shrineとしました。

sen.j: 平安時代末期の藤原明衡の著である『新猿楽記』には、巫女に必要な4要素として「占い・神遊・寄絃・口寄」が挙げられており、彼が実際に目撃したという巫女の神遊（神楽）はまさしく神と舞い遊ぶ仙人のようだったと、記している。
sen.e: According to the "Shin-sarugoki" (a textbook written about lives and cultures of the people of Kyoto in Heian era) by FUJIWARA no Akihira in late Heian era, the four elements required for miko (a shrine maiden) to master were the abilities of uranai (fortune-telling,) kami-asobi (to play music and dance in front of gods,) yotsura (to beat out strings of Japanese bows as a ritual to ward off evil spirits) and kuchiyose (mediumship or technique to communicate with spirits); while Akihira described in this book his actual experience that he had witnessed a miko maiden playing Kamiasobi (Kagura) which looked as if an immortal mountain wizard was enjoying dancing with a god.

sen.j: また、少し後の時代に属する『梁塵秘抄』にある「鈴はさや振る藤太巫女」にも鈴を持ちながら舞い踊る巫女が登場する。
sen.e: There is an anthology of then-current popular songs titled "Ryojin-hisho" (literally, "Songs to make the dust dance on the beams") which belongs to a little bit later age than "Shin-sarugoki" and contains a scene of miko (named Tota) who danced a dance swinging a bell in her hand, in its phrase, "Is it the manner to swing the bell, Tota miko?"

sen.j: 中世の巫女舞に関する多くの史料が残されている備前国（岡山県）の吉備津神社の例では、1342年（康永元年/興国3年）作成の『一宮社法』によれば、一宮（吉備津神社）には12名の巫女からなる「神子座」があり、一宮の行事以外でも村々の招きに応じて神楽を舞い、逆に村々の巫女が一宮で舞う事があった。
sen.e: Many historical documents about Mikomai of medieval age have been kept at Kibitsu Jinja Shrine in Bizen Province (Okayama Prefecture,) and according to one of these documents named "Ichinomiyasha ho" made in 1342, Ichinomiya (i.e. Kibitsu Jinja Shrine) had retained "mikoza" (literally, "a group of miko") composed of twelve miko maidens and dispatched some of them to offer Kagura to local shrines upon their request while Ichinomiya had also received miko maidens from local shrines to let them dance Kagura at Ichinomiya.
sen.cmt: 一宮社法→Ichinomiyasha ho (一宮社法)[定訳不明,読み方が見つからず、仮訳です。]

sen.e: Many historical documents about mikomai in the medieval period have been kept at Kibitsu-jinja Shrine in Bizen Province (Okayama Prefecture), and according to one documents named "Ichinomiyasha ho" written in 1342, Ichinomiya (i.e. Kibitsu-jinja Shrine) retained 'mikoza' (literally, 'a group of miko') composed of twelve shrine maidens, some of whom were dispatched to offer Kagura at local shrines upon request, while Ichinomiya also received shrine maidens from local shrines to dance Kagura at Ichinomiya.
sen.cmt: Kibitsu-jinja Shrineとし、一部シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: だが、1471年（文明 (日本)3年）に作成された「総社家社僧中神前御祈念之事等注文」によれば、巫女にも宮神子から選抜される一神子と一般の宮神子、村方の神子に分類され、一神子のみが本社で神楽を無言で舞うことが許され（託宣などの禁止）、宮神子は祈祷のみを許され、占い・託宣・湯立は脇殿で宮神子以外の者が行うことなどが定められて、神事に携わるものと託宣などを行うものが分離されるようになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, according to the "Soshake Shaso chu Shinzen Gokinen no koto nado Chumon" (literally, "the regulations on prayers to be performed in front of gods by Buddhist monks who belong to all successive shrine priest families") written in 1471, miko (shrine maidens) were classified into Miya miko (literally, "miko maidens belonging to shrine families) and Murakata no miko (literally, "miko maidens belonging to village people) and Miya miko were further classified into Ichi no miko (literally, "the first rank miko") and other general Miya miko, while only Ichi no miko (the first rank shrine maidens) were allowed to dance Kagura silently (but prohibited to make oracles and other performances,) and generally Miya miko were able to offer prayers only but not fortune-telling, oracle and yutate (a ceremony to boil fresh and pure water in front of gods and splash it) which were conducted at wakiden (a hall standing nearby main hall) by others than Miya miko, thus concerned parties became divided into ones in charge of divine affairs and others engaged in other affairs including oracles.

On the other hand, according to the "Soshake Shaso chu Shinzen Gokinen no koto nado Chumon" (literally, "the regulations on prayers to be performed in front of gods by Buddhist monks who belong to all successive shrine priest families") written in 1471, shrine maidens were separated into miko responsible for divine affairs and those engaged in other affairs including oracles, by classifying them into Miya miko (literally "shrine maidens belonging to shrine families) and Murakata no miko (literally "shrine maidens belonging to village people), and further classifying Miya miko as either Ichi no miko (literally "the first rank miko") or other general Miya miko, with only the first rank shrine maidens being allowed to dance Kagura silently (but prohibited to make oracles and other performances) and Miya miko generally permitted to offer prayers only but not allowed to engage in fortune-telling, oracles and yutate (a ceremony to boil fresh pure water and perform ablution by splashing it on themselves in front of gods), which were conducted at wakiden (a hall standing nearby main hall) by shrine maidens other than Miya miko.

sen.e: On the other hand, according to the 'Soshake Shaso chu Shinzen Gokinen no koto nado Chumon' (literally, 'the regulations on prayers to be performed in front of gods by Buddhist monks who belong to all successive shrine priest families') written in 1471, shrine maidens were separated into miko responsible for divine affairs and those engaged in other affairs including oracles, by classifying them into Miya miko (literally, shrine maidens belonging to shrine families) and Murakata no miko (literally, shrine maidens belonging to village people), and further classifying Miya miko as either Ichi no miko (literally, the first rank miko) or other general Miya miko, with only the first rank shrine maidens being allowed to dance Kagura silently (but prohibited to make oracles and other performances) and Miya miko generally permitted to offer prayers only but not allowed to engage in fortune-telling, oracles and yutate (a ceremony to boil fresh pure water and perform ablution by splashing it on themselves in front of gods), which were conducted at wakiden (a hall standing nearby main hall) by shrine maidens other than Miya miko.

sen.j: ところが、江戸時代後期に勃興した国学の中には、神霊の憑依などの霊的現象を淫祠邪教として否定的に捉える学説が現れるようになり、そのような民間習俗と結びつきやすい巫女そのものに対しても否定的な動きが出始めた。
sen.e: However, in late Edo era, some theories of the Kokugaku (study of ancient Japanese literature and culture) rose into power insisting that any spiritual phenomenon including shinrei no hyoi (spirit possession) should be considered as inshi jakyo (evil heresies), thus inducing negative campaign against miko maiden itself which tends to link with the same kind folkways.

However, some Kokugaku (study of ancient Japanese literature and culture) theories that rose to prominence in the late Edo period asserted that any spiritual phenomenon including shinrei no hyoi (spirit possession) should be considered as inshi jakyo (evil heresies), which led to a negative campaign against shrine maidens themselves, who tended to be linked with such folkways.

sen.j: 後、明治維新を迎え、国学的な神道観を基に神社祭祀制度の抜本的な見直しが為されたが、1873年（明治6年）には神霊の憑依などによって託宣を得る行為は教部省によって全面的に禁止された。
sen.e: Later, in the wake of Meiji Restoration, the government reviewed the whole system of divine rituals at shrine from the viewpoint of Kokugaku on Shinto religion, and subsequently in 1873, Kyobu-sho (the Ministry of Religious Education) banned totally any activity to obtain oracles of gods by spirit possession and other spiritual methods.

sen.j: これは巫女禁断令と通称される。
sen.e: This ordinance of prohibition was commonly called Miko-Kindan-rei (an order to forbid miko maidens to obtain divine oracles by spirot possession.)

sen.j: 禁止措置によって神社に常駐せずに民間祈祷を行っていた巫女は全面的に廃業となったが、中には神社に留まることによって活動を続ける者もいた。
sen.e: This order compelled miko maidens, who do not stay constantly at any shrine, to give up their jobs to offer folk prayers among public, but some maidens could continue their activities by staying at some shrines.

Although this order compelled shrine maidens who did not remain continually at one shrine to give up their duty of offering folk prayers among the public, some maidens could continue their activities by staying at some shrines.

sen.j: 後、春日大社の富田光美らが、巫女の神道における重要性を唱えて巫女舞の存続を訴えると同時に同社ゆかりの「八乙女」による舞をより洗練させて芸術性を高める事によって巫女及び巫女舞の復興に尽くしたのである。
sen.e: Afterwards, Mitsuyoshi TOMITA and other members from Kasugataisha shrine appealed importance of miko (shrine maidens) in Shinto religion and pleaded for continuation of Mikomai, and, what's more, they contributed to the restoration of miko and Mikomai by refining its original Mikomai dance performed by "Yaotome" (literally, eight maidens) to boost its artistic quality.

sen.j: これが今日見られるような巫女舞になっていくのであるが、依然として「神がかり」の系統を受け継いだ古い形の巫女舞を残している神社も僅かながら存在している。
sen.e: Thus, Mikomai has developed itself to become that of current style, although there can be seen some, albeit rare, old style of Mikomai with its tradition of "kamigakari" (literally, "spiritual possession.")
Thus even though mikomai has developed into the style seen today, there still remain some older, albeit rare, style of mikomai with its tradition of "kamigakari" (literally, "spiritual possession").
